It wasn't this bad even on reddit.

There the admins banned subreddit mods until the guild was without mods, then banned the subreddit for being unmoderated.

Here they banned the guildmaster and essentially handed it over to someone who is hostile to the guild's original purpose, who then proceeds to destroy the community and exile all the users and kick all the posts. Reddit on steroids.

body: The RCP "cabal" is indeed just a trolling guild run by @carpathianflorist (shocking, I know). But special treatment is undoubtedly given to certain users: the admins pick certain users they think are better than everyone else, and make them mods of the server and assign them authority in many different domains, and give them many special privileges and allow them to break the rules that everyone else has to follow, and listen to their input more than everyone else.

body: DefaultMods is an organization on reddit, aka "the cabal" of power users and admins: people like spez, gallowboob, bardfinn, akwardtheturtle, etc. It's very rare to only mod one default sub, since almost every sub is controlled by DefaultMods, and almost every active DefaultMods member mods 2170483728953 subreddits. All mods of default subs are in DefaultMods, and no one outside of DefaultMods is a mod of those subs. captainmeta4 used to be in it.
body_html: DefaultMods is an organization on reddit, aka "the cabal" of power users and admins: people like spez, gallowboob, bardfinn, akwardtheturtle, etc. It's very rare to only mod one default sub, since almost every sub is controlled by DefaultMods, and almost every active DefaultMods member mods 2170483728953 subreddits. All mods of default subs are in DefaultMods, and no one outside of DefaultMods is a mod of those subs. captainmeta4 used to be in it.

body:
Check the guildmasters of +BetaFeedback, +WatchRedditDie, and +technology.

They also:

* Are allowed to alpha test and give feedback on experimental features that the admins are dead-set on keeping secret to everyone else (focus group)

* Get access to certain "trusted" insider info

* Get more rewards from the admins

* Were planned to be given limited *admin privileges* (this one was conveniently scrapped after I told people about it).

* Have write access to the ruqqus codebase

* Are taken more seriously by the admins in general

* Any other special role, you can bet they got picked for it, usually without even asking for it.
body_html:
Check the guildmasters of +BetaFeedback, +WatchRedditDie, and +Technology.

They also:

  • Are allowed to alpha test and give feedback on experimental features that the admins are dead-set on keeping secret to everyone else (focus group)

  • Get access to certain "trusted" insider info

  • Get more rewards from the admins

  • Were planned to be given limited admin privileges (this one was conveniently scrapped after I told people about it).

  • Have write access to the ruqqus codebase

  • Are taken more seriously by the admins in general

  • Any other special role, you can bet they got picked for it, usually without even asking for it.

parent.body:
There's a difference between the original GM of a guild and sieging the guild to take power. Both instances can still have power GMs who can be abusive moderators (as many consider @milkit), but with sieges there's no credibility to the new GM.

They didn't create the guild. Often it's hijacking like this instance make the new GM worse than the original GM.

Hijacking has almost no credibility to the GMs who then go on to exile half the guild, kick almost all the posts, and then flip the guild on its head.

I agree censorship is bad, but milkit is practically an angel compared to a lot of the hijacking GMs we see. Even compared, I wouldn't say @milkit is perfect or not censoring people. But at the same time, I'm glad he exiles annoying shills, and if they don't like how he runs his guild they have every opportunity to create their own (+LeMemery).

However, all hijacking does is destroy. It destroys guilds, it alienates the original members, it is the pinnacle of moderator abuse, and it quite frankly is a big detractor of the site right now.

I've made a long post about my opinion of sieging here: https://ruqqus.com/+SiegedGuilds/post/5szv/my-general-opinion-on-sieging-probably

parent.body: I feel like a lot of the drama could be avoided by making it against the rules to siege a guild in bad faith.  I'm not a member of any of JG's guilds (to my knowledge), but having a built in mechanism that allows people to change the entire purpose of a guild out of spite is a disservice to anyone who isn't part of one of these pissing contests.
parent.body_html: I feel like a lot of the drama could be avoided by making it against the rules to siege a guild in bad faith. I'm not a member of any of JG's guilds (to my knowledge), but having a built in mechanism that allows people to change the entire purpose of a guild out of spite is a disservice to anyone who isn't part of one of these pissing contests.

post.body:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.
post.body_html:
One of the core tenets of freedom of speech is that all speech - and all users - should be treated equally. To that end, we have site policies about the use of multiple accounts to bypass per-user limitations and other restrictions. These limits are in place for a reason, and circumventing them is unfair to other users.

Generally, when we detect a user with multiple accounts abusing the site, we apply a temporary ban to the main account and a permanent ban to their alternate accounts. Historically, we've been identifying the "main" account as the one with the earliest signup date. However, that's created an issue where someone's primary Ruqqus account isn't the first one they signed up with.

This issue arose with a recent ban for multi-account abuse, which generated some.... lively... feedback. We have decided that, moving forward, we will use total account activity - specifically, the sum of post count, comment count, and votes cast - to determine which account is a user's main account. Additionally, we will retroactively apply this policy change to that recent ban: the active account will be downgraded from a permanent to temporary ban, and the first account will be changed from a temporary to permanent ban.

Because the guild siege feature is intertwined with permanent/temporary ban status, we will also be reversing sieges that were enabled as a result of the original permanent ban.

Furthermore, it has come to our attention that some of the sieges were themselves conducted using alternate accounts to bypass the siege cooldown. These users and accounts will be dealt with accordingly. We will also adjust some siege logic to hopefully prevent alts from bypassing the siege cooldown, and also to prevent banned users from immediately losing their guilds.

Merry Christmas,

-the mismanagement

PS: We are also taking your feedback onboard re: categories, and will be reworking the feature in the near future.
